text.p:
We report on the first coherent control experiments on a purely electronic exciton state in an extended
and quasi-perfect single organic quantum wire, a polydiacetylene chain in the crystalline matrix of its own
monomer.

On such a system, we have previously evidenced the spatial macroscopic coherence of the excitonic
emission [1]. We have also performed the first coherent control of a photocreated vibronic state on a single
chain and deduced its short coherence time directly [2].

Here two phase-locked picosecond pulses are used to excite the first purely electronic excitonic state (zero
phonon) of the chain. The chain is in a first step excited at the same position by the two consecutive pulses and
we measure its time-integrated emission. The relative phase between the phase-locked laser pulses is varied by
means of a stabilized scanning interferometer. With such a set up, the relative phase ϕ can be precisely adjusted
as well as the delay τ between the two pulses. For a given delay τ, the intensities of the emission spectra for
ϕ = 0 and π, respectively I(τ,0) and I(τ,π), is measured and the emission contrast, C, defined as
(I(τ,0)-I(τ,π))/(I(τ,0)+I(τ,π)) is computed.

The experiments are performed in the weak photon-exciton coupling regime. The influence of dynamical
disorder on the overall decoherence time T 2 is explored as shown in the figure where the characteristic
deceasing times are deduced from a first approach through a two levels model.

By means of microscopic imaging spectroscopy using a micro-photoluminescence setup coupled to an
imaging spectrometer the emission of the organic quantum wire is also imaged when the relative phase between
pulses is varied. Coherent control over the whole chain length is in this manner demonstrated [3].

Moreover preliminary results of coherent control when the chain is excited on two spatially separated
places are presented.
